reviewText:
Intergalactic Bubbles is inspired by a game I don't remember the name but I can still see the cursor, the dinosaur and the bubble being sent. It's not  Bubble Bobble though I think there was an arcade version with a different gameplay. Anyway, I've known this game under different names, the last one being on a giveaway game where the minigame is called Blink Shooter and is my favorite.

The goal is to send colored balls on others of the same color to explode them and make sure that the board is cleaned before they're descending and touch your line. By doing so, you can also get rid of balls under them if they're not attached to another one that will support everything. Here, you have also the balls moving naturally, like if there was gravity and can also tied themselves to others and if they're the same color, you'll have another explosion that will probably help you to reach your goal.

Intergalactic Bubbles is challenging because if you want to upgrade bonuses, you need to collect a sort of stars (that look more like a planet on fire anyway). Each level completed will give you one but if you do it less than the number if balls sent that will be displayed, you'll collect 3 or 2 stars.

The game is kinda long if you're aiming like me to a 3 stars. The more you advance, more balls will be on the board or a new color is added.

While the graphics aren't spectacular and really simple, the soundtrack is correct.

I suppose that some people will be deceived by the lack of features, but it's enough for me. I find the game a little too slow, mainly in the speed at which the board is descending.

If you love that kind of games, you can go for it, it's a nice disctraction.

Edit: Apparently, the game was Bust-A-Move. The name itself is clicking in my head though I can't be sure if I was that.
voteText: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fun ball shooter.

I played a lot of this on Desura, so my Steam time is misleading.

This is a ball shooter game with a twist.  There's phyiscs that affects how the balls move.  Sometimes that ends up in your favor as a dangling trail of balls will swing back and forth and might attach to others which will activate them and make them explode.  Other times the physics is a hindrance when a dangling trail swings by at the wrong moment and grabs the ball you intended to go elsewhere.

There's an upgrade tree that you spend points on.  Get points by finishing a level in under a certain amount of balls spent.  You can replay levels any time as much as you want.

3 Bonuses: Wild, Bomb, and Rocket.  Each time you make a match it starts to power up your bonus meter.  Once it is full you can choose a bonus to use.

This is a slower paced ball shooter than others I've played.  I find the emphasis to be more on strategy, especially if you want to use as few balls as possible to get the 3 star rating.  And sometimes you can waste a ball if you don't wait for the ones you just shot to fall because your new ball might attach to the falling ones.

There's no story, just fun arcade ball shooting.

Music is nice.  I like it.

Graphics are okay.  I'm not picky about graphics, though.

I find myself having to force myself to quit.  Just one more level!""

reviewText:
It's like one of those other bubble games, but it has something extra. First of all, this has physics. The balls have weight and that means when a group is holding on with just 1 bubble connection, the whole group just swings a bit. The momentum goes away of course, but when it first goes in motion, it can either “catch” the ball you just shot (if you shot it) or it can connect to something else and if the balls are of the same colour, they act as a ball that you shot.
Second neat thing about this game are the upgrades and powerups. You upgrade your launcher to have energy which is gained by bubbles that fall down. Energy you use to activate powerups: launch ball ABOVE the “playground” to selected spot, use a rainbow ball or use a bomb. The powerups themselves are also upgradeable.
There are few flaws though, but they're rather minor. Graphics are a bit bad, too though, but gameplay is what counts. Gameplay first, graphics later.

Lil' Sucky Gameplay to go with the review.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mqRybbmaQtI

reviewText:
This game in 2min
https://youtu.be/NHUawoo1pv4

I'm sure you've seen this game before under another name or own it on your mobile.
you launch bubble down a lane and try hit 2 or more of the same color to make them pop.
you win by clearing the board by popping all bubbles or making them fall down.

This game add power ups & every level setup is random.
by using less then a set number of bubbles on a board you can get 1-3 items that can be used to upgrade abilities but you'll need 5x each ability level to upgrade it (L1 needs 5, L2=10, ect until L5).
most are things like more bubbles can touch the bottom before you lose, more energy for your 3 main abilities, and faster ways to gain energy.
the 3 main attack abilities are
1)a launcher that lets you toss a bubble up into the mass.
2)a multi color bubble that will pop any 2 or more bubble it touches regardless of color.
3)a bomb that takes out all bubble in a set range.
these all have upgrades and also you can unlock the ability to do 2 or all 3 with 1 bubble.

reviewText:
Intergalactic Bubbles is a Puzzle Bobble/Bust A Move puzzle game.  You match 3 bubbles of the same color to remove them from the board.  Doing so in a certain number of turns gets you a one to three star rating.  What makes this different from other puzzle games like this is the upgrades and physics.

The physics are interesting for this.  Once you remove three bubbles of the same color, the surrounding bubbles sway and if they collide with three or more of the same color, boom they are removed.  You can get a nice chain reaction going if done right and everything works out in your favor.

Upgrades are also interesting.  You can use rockets, bombs, and other upgrades to remove certain difficult areas".  This helps you get that 3 star rating you might be looking for in a certain stage.

If you enjoy this type of puzzle game
date: I highly recommend this.  There are quite a few levels to go through and it is different enough to make it worth your time."
helpfulPercent: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I like this type of games.  I mean games with colorful balls where you have to match them using your quick reflexes and accuracy ( Sadly there very few of those especially for SteamOS/Linux). This game managed to entertain me for 5-15 minutes sessions, but not longer.

Positive:
It has many levels. It took me 14 hours to complete all levels and earn all stars
Ability to upgrade / buy weapons adds some variety/tactics to game.
Negative:
Annoying sound effects and music
Mediocre graphics
Monotonous gameplay. You will get more lines (bubbles) in later levels and additional color in new worlds.
Annoying  bugs: you can shoot and get stuck to falling bubbles, Restart level sometimes works and sometimes doesn't
Not very well balanced.  First world was too easy. (Only 3 colors) Last 1.5 worlds were also only formality, because i already earned powerful upgrades, which helped me to gain 3 stars in all levels without any challenge.
Despite more bad than goods sides  i recommenced this game for fans of Bubble Puzzle / Zuma and similar games.  Especially for price 1  EUR or even less on sales

I am enjoying this game. It is the best (USD) $0.49 I've spent in a LONG time. The basic principles are easy to grasp and if you start out on a skill tree and change your mind it is easy to correct - Or just start over.
It is one of those games that I'm just gonna play for a few minutes" and then... "Opps! Where did the time go?"

There is one MAJOR problem though. - Like about 10% of men in America
date: I have "male pattern color-blindness."  - We see colors
recommended: we just don't always see them correctly.  So... when I get to Androdema and they "add a color" - The mottled Yellow and the mottled Green look almost identical.... to me.\nI run into this trouble fairly often with computer games. Usually when some "vital message" is flashed on a screen in Red... it looks grey to me. - But I'm having fun anyway. And even if I can't pass on to advanced "galaxies" - at this price - that's evough."

A game like a porn clip. You actually dont need it but damn its satisfying as ♥♥♥♥.

Have five minutes to spare? Five hours? No matter how long you can play, Intergalactic Bubbles will take it. If you liked Bust-A-Move or Puzzle Bobble you will love this game. It's the same concept but they've turned it on its head. If you enjoy puzzle games you will have fun playing Intergalactic Bubbles.

date: this one uses a slightly angled 3D perspective

reviewText: The ball physics are particularly hypnotic.\n\nA very relaxing and enjoyable casual game.

You've seen them before, you've probably tried a few of them - Bubble-shooter-games!

This one is no difference, except you got 3 powers you can invoke to help you clear the masses of colourful balls coming towards you while you try banding an impossible hit.

With 150 levels it will keep you entertained for quite some time, however do take breaks, it's best for you and your hospital bills.

Thumbsup:
Plenty of levels to clear
Difficult enough to fail getting 3 stars at first try every 5'th map or so.
Sometimes every ball will spin in a tornado - pretty pretty

Sadface:
Might be too easy
I don't think you can play it windowed - only full screen. So you can't stream your favourite movie meanwhile.

Anyway have fun, it kept me busy for many days :p

reviewText:
It plays well, it's just kind of...boring. The gameplay has been done many times before. The graphics are very simple 3D, with a plain metal playing field and only a vaguely space-esque background to break up the monotony. The music is repetitive, non-melodic synth stuff. The one reasonably innovative thing is that the spheres hang together and swing around using some simple physics.

You can sit there and play for a while, and space out, and waste time...but afterwards you wonder why you even bothered.

reviewText:
Well, I'm torn. On one hand, this game has such a cheap pricetag that there's really no way you could could not pick this up - especially when it's on sale. If you see this game on sale pick it up; but there's a few things that irk me about it.

Firstly, the thing that I'm really not a huge fan about is how simplistic everything looks, evidently the game could be the nicest looking game out there and not really change anything.

What you really should note about this game is that it is so simplistic to the point that yes, it is pure brilliance. I would even go as far as to say that this game is great. The main pointers about why it's so great is because; It's cheap, it's easy to run, there's not much of a learning curve and well, it's fun.

Do get this game if it's on sale. It's worth your time and money.

reviewText:
(I've played hours of this on my phone. This version is virtually identical.)

Intergalactic Bubbles will feel both familiar and innovative to puzzle game fans. The sticky physics are what make it awesome -- big tendrils and gobs of bubbles swing and pop and fall spinning off the map. They enhance the feel of the game and, once you're used to them, they can be leveraged for tactical combos.

The sorta pinball table view is a nice touch too.

Very good instincts shown by this dev. I'm gonna keep my eye on 'em.

reviewText:
Instead of picking up something like bubble witch saga on your phone, only to have to pay bucketloads in micro-transactions to actually progress, you could pick this up for under the euro.

Gameplay wise it's pretty much identical to games like bubble witch saga, only there's actual physics which makes the balls swing as you hit them, and there's an upgrade system, which makes it differ abit from simular games.

Graphic wise it looks quite unpolished and amatuerlike, but then would you expect anyhing else for 0.99 euro.

Overall the gameplay makes up for the graphics and it's kindoff an addicting game, also a great time waster if you're waiting for some other game to install, or if you're generally bored.

I would suggest picking this up.

A nice, fast-paced Bust-A-Move/Snood type game, with attractive 3d spacy marbles.

It feels a bit more frantic than its predecessors as the marbles are constantly moving toward you at a steady rate, rather than moving a fixed distance every time you make a move, so you can't take as long as you want to line up the perfect shot. Also, the marbles fire at a rather high velocity from your gun, and the physics mean targets may swing wildly for a while before they settle, which creates an interesting departure from the originals.

Plays smoothly on Linux.

[Bought at significant discount during 2015 Holiday Sale]

When I bought this game it was 3:30 in the morning and I was bored with nothing to do (you know other than going to sleep). So I decided to get a new game. I didn't have a lot of money left in my Steam account, and I need to find something with a low price. That's when I stumbled upon this hidden gem of a game. I have many fond memories of playing puzzle games similar to this one when I was younger, and the trailer of the game showed that it had to offer than the other bubble games created in the past; so I decided to give it a try. I found myself blazing through each level and having fun experimenting with the game's unique power up system. I am sure I will spend plenty of time playing this game if I find myself with a small window of free time, or I desire to play a game that is simply relaxing and stimulating for the brain. My only complaint I have so far with this game is that it bland soundtrack. I would suggest having some music that you enjoy playing in another window while playing this game.

An easy and nice game to spend a few hours with. Dynamics and tricks are quite simple and intuitive; background music and sounds are very nice. The special weapons and combinations added a new layer to an old-type game.

PROs:
- Commands and dynamics are really easy to grasp. You likely won't need the step-by-step introduction - but it's there, neverthless, if you need it.
- Music and sounds. Like I said, they did a great job with it. They can be easily muted and regulated through the game, too.
- Special weapons and their combinations. Nothing is as viscerally satisfying as being able to get the whole table to explode with just one move.

CONs:
- The level of simplicity. Really, the whole game is almost too easy. You get almost at once the right, intuitive combination of exploding bubbles and special weapons needed to pass the harder levels. Conversely, the last sector is literally impossible to win with full stars and without special weapons; you'd need to try and try and try again until you get a lucky screen.
- The colours. Blue, green and red, all right. But, add the yellow one to the mix and it gets really hard to pick them apart - and I'm not even vaguely color-blind. (And then comes the orange... no, really. There were moments when I had to stop and look at them a second time.)

Going just by genre, I'd say 8/10. As a more general vote, a nice 7/10. I'll be likely re-playing this sometimes soon and I've already suggested it to other players.

Intergalactic Bubbles is hardly an original game design; it's one of those simple games that get cloned ad nauseam, like Arcanoid or Tetris. Nevertheless, such clones are invariably entertaining because their core idea is so good, and if they manage to give it some nice twist, they can expect some real popularity.\nThis is exactly what Intergalactic Bubbles does: by taking the concept of put balls of the same colour together to make them disappear" and adding real physics
date: as well as some special moves and buyable upgrades

reviewText:
I love Bust-a-move, so Intergalactic Bubbles is the sort of game that would get my attention quite quickly. On a simple level, this is taking the classic Bust-a-Move game style and putting it in a 3d situation. It does do that, and for the price, I'd say it's definitely worth the money, but I do have to say that there's some missteps with the game.

First of all, Bust-a-Move had a lot of interesting level design, something that's entirely absent here. There's 5 'worlds' of 50 levels each, and each new world adds an extra color into the mix. However, within a world, every single level is basically the same, you have solid rows of bubbles and higher levels simply have more rows. As the number of rows increments slowly, this means that every single level in a world feels basically the same as the one before it. It ends up feeling very monotonous and repetitive, and even a handful of change-ups in there would make it more engaging. The other issue in this vein is the power-up system. There's really too many options in the power-ups, and it somewhat bothers me that having beaten the game, I can't unlock everything on the power-up tree. There is also that by having the right power-ups, the game goes from very challenging, to beating every level in about half the required shots. I flew through about the last 20 levels because of the right power-up combination making this, imo, too easy.

There's also a few issues with the rendering. The shots that take advantage of the 3rd dimension seem to have a nasty habit of getting stuck somewhere slightly earlier than what the arrow would indicate, which is really frustrating. There is also that the bubbles don't always handle occupying the same space well, and you can have a chain reaction of glitches virtually clear the board sometimes. I beat levels in only about 10 shots a few times because a glitch would happen in one corner, and take out the entire field. It basically finishes the level for you, so on one hand, that's sort of convenient and it's a bit harder to get made about it, but on the other hand it's a bit frustrating and it sometimes meant that I had to restart the game to get the controls working normally again.

Overall, while there's a few interesting mechanics on top of the classic Bust-a-move (such as using momentum of bubbles to make connections), it's a bit lacking, but still good entertainment for the price (a buck or two)

Not too fast-paced - a sweet Match-3 game.

I was, however, GREATLY IMPRESSED at the trick shots that are possible. You've got skill? You can make some pretty slick moves. And THAT is a satisfying experience, when you pull one off!

I've spent 10 times as much on other games, and haven't had as much fun. I wanted to write this review in support of a simple, subtle, tidy game about focus and called shots. (I went through levels like potato chips.)

I'd love to see a sequel, with variations or deeper power-ups and abilities. I'd love to see this get attention. Thanks, developers - - cool stuff.

Many many years ago my grandmother had an old bubble popping game on an old-old-ancient desktop computer. I used to play it for hours.  This is just like that, but better.  Worth the 2 bucks, imo.  It's a great little time waster when you don't want a deeply involved game.

Puzzle Bobble was a LOT more polished.  Intergalactic Bubbles  has power ups.

The first thing that I noticed on this game was that the graphics and typography was pretty basic.  This is usually a coin-flipper on whether the game is going to be decent.  Usually, if I'm looking at something not intentionally throwback, it means that the developers didn't want to take the time to add polish to the game.  And then... the music.  The music is this generic couldabeen music that is designed to slip into the background and quietly suck there.  Really, it's repetitive and doesn't have anything interesting going on with it.

That said, once I started playing, I ended up in that half-flow zone playing level after repetitive level, enjoying myself.  I had some frustration with not being able to flip the balls, but I did like the physics 'touch' that was added to it.  The game itself is rather hyptnotic... I had played for half an hour before I realized that I'd played that long.  It's soothing in the same manner that Chuzzle Deluxe Zen mode is soothing.

I bought this on sale, though I'd pay full price for it as well.
chance of a life time\n10/10 get this game and all problems will be solved

reviewText: GOOD

I didnt play much so far, but I'm already in love with this Bubble Shooter game. And why is that? Read this review for god sake!! XD

But anyways, if you ever saw this game before in the store, and you thought ''Oh, just a normal Buuble Shooter game, again, meh''. I understand your reaction. I had the same reaction when I first saw the game. Then the game was in sale, and since it was like 23 cents I think, I bought it.

When I first played it, oh I see, an Unity game... I wasnt expecting much now...

But when I played my first game, you can, unlike other bubble shooters, combo your shots. And this is what makes the game AMAZING. Its so fun and satisfying to do these combos!!! The idea is very well-thought. This is the best bubble shooter game I ever played. But wait, theres more.

The music is calm, and fits very well for a game in space (Its INTERGALATIC Bubbles). Heck, I would love to have the soundtrack actually.

The controls are great and perfect. Nothing more to say. No controller support, but who wants to play a bubble shooter with a controller?

The 3D graphics are very enjoyable even though they are simple. The simple look of the graphics makes the game run very smoothly, and smooth gameplay is a very good thing.


In conclusion, your wallet will be very happy after you buy this game. Its worth the price. Trust me. This is probably the best bubble shooter game around.

101% RECOMMENDED!!!!!!

Intergalactic Bubbles is a Match-3-Esque Bubble Shooter. An incredibly simple game, at its core, but, with a twist. It has about 250 Levels and will last quite a while (It took me 3 Hours to get past the first 50 Levels). This game has power ups which allow for a unique twist to the Bubble Shooter Genre. One allows you to place it anywhere in the area, one is a Universal Ball, and the other, which I forget. There is also a layer of physics here as well. You can bounce the Ball off a wall and ricochet it to hit where you want, if you're good enough to do that. Furthermore, you can upgrade the Abilities when you have points, which will give you better uses for the Ability. You can even combine the Abilities later in the game when you get far enough. I would definently recommend this game if you like the Bubble Shooter Genre. It is Cheap, fun, unique, and definently worth every penny.
